title: Full Assessment of Lung Mechanics Using Computer-Controlled, Forced Oscillation Technique
procedures:
The FlexiVentFX™ system is a modular system where different modules are connected to the main chassis (Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002]–C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002]), which handles all communication with the attached computer.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/17e531b2-48f5-43c0-80a7-ad227aa4b3a1/cpz1488-fig-0002-m.jpg

Figure 2 FlexiVentFX™ System main chassis. Parts of the base unit with the cover closed (A) and opened (B). The back view of the base unit (C) with zoom shot on I/O ports (D). For the different types of measurements, different combinations of modules are necessary. Except for the FX modules, all modules are connected with the I/O ports on the main chassis. They have to be attached to the right I/O port to function properly. For this purpose, the I/O ports and the plates attached to the cables of the modules have been color-coded with a little colored label (Fig. 2C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002] and D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002]). For all (dis-)assembly procedures, the system needs to be switched off with the power switch on the main chassis (Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002]). Always check that the system is off (display not lit up) before removing any module or cable. Materials FlexiVentFX™ Base Unit and Module (Scireq Inc.): FlexiVentFX™ main chassis FlexiVentFX™ module Tubing ports Tubing FX1 module Tubing FX2 module Y-connector FX1 module Y-connector FX2 module 1. Prepare the components of the system needed for the desired measurement. For Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0005] and a mouse with a body weight of around 25 g, the following will be needed: FX1 module and FX1 tubing port without nebulizer mount. For an animal weighing 35–85 g: FX2 module and FX2 tubing port without nebulizer mount. 2. Change the FX module. Check that the machine is off and open the cover. If machine is not off, switch it off. The power button is located on the main chassis (Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002]). Unscrew the piston arm from the motor arm (Fig. 3A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0003]).

The motor arm can be moved without risk of damaging the machine. It will recalibrate its position at start-up. Unscrew the FX module from the FlexiVentFX™ chassis (Fig. 4A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0004]). Remove the FX module. Remove the FX module by lifting it upwards. Note that it can only be removed by lifting upwards, as there is a connector on the bottom of the FX modules (Fig. 2C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002]). Remove the protective tube from the FX module to install. Remove the protective tube and the bubble wrap. Place the protective tube on the FX module to store away. Place the bubble wrap on the broad part of the piston arm and put on the protective tube. Install the FX module. Insert the FX module on the main chassis by moving it into place vertically. The connector is located at the bottom. Screw the module to the main chassis (Fig. 5[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0005]). Screw the piston arm to the motor arm (Fig. 4[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0004]). Close the cover of the main chassis.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/e1c8cbef-f208-422e-baa4-44abadb1a6ea/cpz1488-fig-0003-m.jpg

Figure 3 Parts of the FX module (A) and location of the inspiratory air inlet and outlet (B).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/a91fd5f2-c998-44e0-bbe3-34ab9f91a2ec/cpz1488-fig-0004-m.jpg

Figure 4 Connection of the FX module to the motor arm via the piston arm (A) and disengaged motor lock (B).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/23198ff1-8389-4638-b68d-39592954a550/cpz1488-fig-0005-m.jpg

Figure 5 Location of the screw that attaches the FX module to the main chassis. 3. Install the tubing port. Slide the mounts into the slot on the FX module with the plastic attachment's O-ring facing towards the machine and the metal lever up. The FX1 modules use tubing ports made of transparent plastic. Two tubing ports are available, with and without a nebulizer mount (Fig. 6A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0006]). If no pharmacological challenge is needed, select the one without a mount; otherwise use the one with the nebulizer mount.

The FX2 modules use tubing ports made of black plastic. Three tubing ports are available: two for measurement, with or without nebulizer mount, and one for the cleaning of the MSX system (Fig. 6B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0006]). The latter only has two plastic attachments with O-rings and cannot be used for measurements, as it does not connect to the pressure transducer. For this protocol, you will need the tubing ports without nebulizer mount. Connect the tubing assembly if necessary. Usually the tubing remains attached to the tubing port. If this is not the case, put two pieces of tubing on the metal tubes of the tubing port. For measurements with single animal: Connect the tubing on the other end to the Y-shaped connector (Fig. 6A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0006]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/bb6e63c3-8296-47a2-9532-1869bb77e465/cpz1488-fig-0006-m.jpg

Figure 6 Different types of tubing ports for the FX1 module (A) and FX2 module (B).

FLEXIWARE is the software used for measurements with the FlexiVentFX™ systems. It uses a database to store all data that were generated during the measurements. Due to technical restrictions, the database cannot be bigger than 1.5 GB. With bigger databases, the integrity of the data could be compromised. This protocol describes how to create new databases and archive old databases so that no data get lost. To easily trace back data, a strict naming convention is recommended for the databases—no other names should be used at any time. Materials FlexiVentFX™ System (Scireq Inc.) FlexiWare software (Scireq Inc.) installed on a computer Steps for the creation of a new database and archiving of the old database 1. Copy the current database to a safe location for backup. Copy the most recent file with extension .FDB from D:\Flexivent_DB\ to your selected location. For example: \\primus.img.cas.cz\data\18_lab\CCP\Data lung Screen\DB back-ups. 2. Copy the blank database to D:\Flexivent_DB. For example, copy the file D:\Flexivent_DB\Blank\Blank.FDB to D:\Flexivent_DB. 3. Rename the copied blank database. Rename the newly copied file to FVx_YYYY_MM_DD.FDB, where x is the number of the Flexivent (red label on main chassis), YYYY the current year, MM the month (with a 0 in front if <10), and DD the current day (also preceded by 0 if day <10). 4. Open the FlexiWare software and the database management module. Double click the FlexiWare icon. Once the FlexiWare software is open, click on the System Settings icon to open that module (Fig. 7[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0007]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/28367b27-8059-429a-9dcf-6e5850f626b9/cpz1488-fig-0007-m.jpg

Figure 7 The different parts of the FlexiWare welcome dialog. 5. Change the database to the newly created database. In the settings window, navigate to the ‘Experiment database’ tab. Change the ‘Default EDB file’ to the newly created database file. 6. Close the system setting window by clicking OK, and restart the software.

This support protocol describes how to construct the materials made in-house that are presented in the basic protocols. These include the intubation platform and confirmation module for Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0004]. One should be able to construct the platform and module provided that all the materials below are available. We suggest seeking the help of your institution's electronics and engineering department, as the majority of the materials are available from their workshops, and a basic understanding of circuit building is necessary.
Materials
For the construction of the intubation platform:
               
Polystyrene plexiglas, 200 × 485 × 4 (Gutta, 4003412026749)
Plexiglas sheet cutter (Fruugo, 73641867-147939002)
Drill and drill bits (FTM, Inc., BG4650A)
Super glue (Bison Germany, 80273)
3, M8 × 200 mm Head bolts/screws with nuts and washers (TIMco, 08200CB)
2, Bolt set with spring washers (Schwer Fittings GmbH, SAE-SET-M8 × 30)
25-cm Nylon string (Ibanez, ICLS6NT)
Waterproof plastic electronic box (100 × 68 × 50 mm; Digital Zakka, 00884322)
For the construction of intubation confirmation module:
               
Circuit board (90 × 150 mm) (Techfun.sk, DPS7920)
Soldering iron (Powerplus, POWX1382)
Solder (Pecka Modeler, 5601-199)
Airspeed sensor Mpxv7002 dp with air hose (Fruugo, 80046867-165799705)
Arduino Nano V2.0 or higher (Arduino, dratek.cz 1449953245)
5 Metallic resistors (100 Ohm, 1% Tolerance) (GYM/CYM, MF0207101FTB)
5 LEDs (5 mm, 25 mA) (LED Technology, L07R5000Q1)
MicroUSB-USB 2.0 0.5 m cable (hb-digital.de, AQ, 5398-001)
AC EURO Adapter 220V to USB (500 mA) (Joyetech, BEK-QC-001)
Wires (The Pi Hut, 103745)
A. Steps for the construction of intubation platform
1. Procure all the materials listed in the materials list above.

The size of the polystyrene plexiglas may vary as long as the dimensions of the three pieces of the platform fit. Plexiglas is a brand of poly(methyl methacrylate) or PMMA. Other trade names may be utilized. The plexiglas sheet cutter and drill presented above are simple handheld tools. Your institution's workshop may have more sophisticated cutters and drills. We suggest consulting your engineering department. 2. Divide the plexiglas into pieces as needed. Mark the plexiglas as shown in Figure 8A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0008]. The broken lines in Figure 8A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0008] represent where to cut, while the circles indicate where to drill holes. Cut the plexiglas into pieces using a cutter. There are two identical trapezoidal pieces and one rectangular piece. The inclination in the trapezoidal pieces will provide support to the body of the animal during intubation.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/cd0add12-6116-42ee-bec9-29db9b6e3735/cpz1488-fig-0008-m.jpg

Figure 8 Construction of the intubation platform. (A) The layout of the 970-cm2 Plexiglas with divisions designated by broken lines to be used as guide for cutting. Dimensions of the pieces and location of where to bore holes are indicated. The assembled intubation platform is presented in (B). The holes in the side pieces are identically lettered in A to show connections in B. 3. Bore holes into the plexiglas where the bolts will be inserted. Use a drill and appropriate bits to bore holes. Note that the locations of the holes in the trapezoidal pieces are identical. Make sure that the size of the drill bit is neither too small nor too big for the diameter of the bolts you will use. 4. Assemble the intubation platform. Use Figure 8B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0008] as a guide during assembly. Fix the two, smaller, 30-mm bolts and washers into the holes of the rectangular piece. Put two hexagonal nuts into the middle of each of the three, longer, 200-mm bolts.

Insert the 200-mm bolts into the holes of each of the trapezoidal pieces. The holes are lettered x, y, and z to indicate connections of the two pieces. Place washers and nuts to keep the plexiglas fastened. Place the rectangular front piece in between the two trapezoidal side pieces. Holding the trapezoidal pieces upright (16-cm side at the bottom), slide the pieces to the side, creating a space for the rectangular piece. Use super glue to stick the rectangular front piece to the trapezoidal side pieces. Adjust the washers and nuts to secure the frame of the platform. 5. Tie the nylon string across the two bolts of the rectangular front frame. B. Steps for the construction of intubation confirmation module 6. Gather all the materials needed as listed in the materials list above. Except for the Airspeed sensor Mpxv7002dp and Arduino Nano V2.0, the rest of the materials are available in different brand names and trademarks. Use the one conveniently available to you. Figure 9A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0009] shows how the different circuit components are located in the module.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/c1d387bc-3314-415a-9e37-977a66bffc23/cpz1488-fig-0009-m.jpg

Figure 9 Construction of the intubation confirmation module. (A) The circuitry of the module with the different parts. (B) Electrical scheme of the module. (C) The back of the circuit board after assembly. (D) The circuitry of the module fitted into the electronic box with the air hose connected to the airspeed sensor. (E) The entirety of the module with the electronic box covered. 7. Set-up the airspeed sensor and nanochip.

The Mpxv7002dp is designed to measure positive and negative pressure: -2 to 2 kPa (-0.3 to 0.3 psi) corresponding to 0.5 to 4.5 V output. The high-level output analog signal is proportional to the applied air pressure created by breathing, as an example. A displacement at a specific voltage, i.e., 2.5 V, allows pressure and vacuum sensing. This explains how incorrect intubation of the animal into the esophagus can create negative pressure due to movement of the diaphragm, while a correct intubation into the lungs produces air pressure changes (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0004]). Follow the instructions of the manufacturer for configuration.
The core of the module is a microcontroller unit (MCU) in Arduino Nano V2.0. Program the MCU following the instructions of the manufacturer. Arduino Nano has several built-in LED pins, digital I/O pins, and analog input pins. Refer to the manual of the MCU to identify these pins for proper assembly into the circuit.
8. Assemble the circuitry of the intubation confirmation module following the electrical scheme in Figure 9B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0009].
Consult an electrician if you do not understand the scheme. The MCU and air speed sensor are shown on the right in yellow, while the resistors (R1-R5) and LEDs (D1-D5) are on the left. The pins in the MCU are numbered and the connections to the other components are indicated. Refer to the product insert of the airspeed sensor for the pin descriptions and numbering.
Cut the circuit board to a size that will fit into the electronic box.
Solder the different parts of the circuitry into the circuit board (Fig. 9C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0009]).

CAUTION: Take necessary safety precautions for soldering. Never touch the heated soldering iron, as this could result into serious burns. We strongly advise asking for an electrician's help if you do not know how to do this properly.
9. Test whether the module is working.
         
Attach the air hose to the pitch of the airspeed sensor and connect the microUSB-USB 2.0 cable and adapter to the microUSB port.
Plug the adapter into the power supply.
Gently blow some air into the air hose.
A functioning module will show a blinking LED left and right. The module may also be tested on an intubated mouse (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0004]). Videos 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0001a] and 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002a] also demonstrate how the module works when constructed properly.
This video cannot be streamed at this time, please download the video instead.[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/3f5ac00a-d49d-4e08-871c-3c7c3c4ede1a/cpz1488-vid-0001.mp4]
Video
Testing for correctness of intubation using confirmation module—intubation done incorrectly. The inlet tube of the improvised intubation confirmation module is attached to the catheter. Irregular blinking of the red LED lights means that the catheter was intubated into the mouse the wrong way.
This video cannot be streamed at this time, please download the video instead.[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/4b78d2ef-12ac-4862-a323-5d65339fcbe0/cpz1488-vid-0002.mp4]
Video
Testing for correctness of intubation using confirmation module—intubation done correctly. The inlet tube of the improvised intubation confirmation module is attached to the catheter. Regular blinking of the red LED lights from left to right and vice versa means that the catheter was intubated correctly into the mouse
10. Secure the circuitry of the module into the plastic electronic box.
         
Place the circuitry of the module into the plastic electronic box (Fig. 9D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0009]).
Bore a hole using a drill for the air hose on the cover of the plastic box.
Create a hole likewise for the power cable on the side of the box (Fig. 9E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0009]).
Screw on the cover of the box.

This protocol presents a simple, inexpensive, and non-invasive procedure to perform mouse endotracheal intubation. This will involve the use of an intubation platform and confirmation module, presented in Support Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0003]. Furthermore, an external LED light source is needed as a guide for intubation (Fig. 10[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0010]). It is important to properly anesthetize the animal with the recommended injection anesthetics and follow necessary animal handling guidelines.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/2b963558-5c23-4468-9e08-762673cd68a9/cpz1488-fig-0010-m.jpg

Figure 10 The complete setup for mouse intubation. NOTE: All protocols involving animals must be reviewed and approved by the appropriate Animal Care and Use Committee and must follow regulations for the care and use of laboratory animals. Materials Mouse Ketamine/xylazine cocktail (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-rec-0001]) Vidisic® Eye Gel (2 mg/g Carbomerum 980; Bausch+ Lomb Czech Republic, Over-the-counter) or alternative ophthalmic ointment with Petrolatum and Mineral oil Intubation platform (made in-house, see Support Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0003]) Blunt ended bent insertion needle Insyte catheter 18G 30 mm (BD, Ref. No. 381244) KL1600 LED cold light source (Schott, Part. No. 150 600) Bent forceps Intubation confirmation module (made in-house, see Support Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0003]) Insulin syringe with needle 500 or 1000 µl (Terumo™, 8SS01H25161) Additional reagents and equipment for injection of rodents (see Current Protocols article: Donovan & Brown, 2006[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-bib-0008]) 1. Weigh the mouse. We usually measure lung function of male or female mice on C57BL/6NCrl background. We run the protocol on mice at a minimum age of 9 and a maximum of 35 weeks. For the IMPC, the lung function phenotyping is being done at 13 weeks of age. If intubation is done for FlexiVentFX™ measurements, write down the weight of the mouse on the lung function report. 2. Anesthetize the mouse by intraperitoneally injecting (Donovan & Brown, the calculated dosage of ketamine/xylazine cocktail.

Ketamine/xylazine cocktail is prepared as described above. The cocktail stays stable at room temperature for 7 days and may be stored in the refrigerator for up to 30 days. For intubations, we use a ketamine/xylazine cocktail that only contains half the amount of xylazine compared to the dosage used for surgery. This will avoid a severe drop in cardiac and respiratory function. We use the following dosage of the ketamine/xylazinexyyxylazine cocktail: 0.1 mg/g body weight/0.01 mg/g body weight. On top of the calculated amount, an additional 100 µl or 50 µl of the cocktail is injected for male or female mice, respectively. The paw reflex will not be gone completely, but as the procedure is not painful, this is not an issue. Apply gel on the eyes of the animal as necessary, to protect against drying. 3. Secure the anesthetized animal to the platform by attaching the mouse to the nylon string of the intubation platform via an upper incisor (Fig. 11[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0011]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/be7fe4f0-f53c-4896-b958-a966af80a0bb/cpz1488-fig-0011-m.jpg

Figure 11 Secured, anesthetized mouse on the intubation platform. 4. Illuminate the windpipe of the animal by positioning the flexible light-guides from the cold light source just below the larynx (Fig. 12[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0012]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/d84b6771-d3f4-42bd-83aa-d74d57f97371/cpz1488-fig-0012-m.jpg

Figure 12 Correct positioning of light source for windpipe illumination. 5. Put the catheter on the needle by sliding the catheter completely over the bent, blunt-ended insertion needle. In an actual experimental scenario, the intubation catheter must be pre-calibrated. See step 7 of Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0005]. 6. Intubate the mouse. a.Grab the tongue of the mouse with the bent forceps. If the mouse reacts, wait 2 min and repeat the procedure. If the mouse is still not asleep after that time, inject 50 µl of ketamine/xylazine i.p. for intubations and wait 5 min. Write down the extra injection on the lung function report.

b.Take the tongue between index and middle finger of the left hand. c.Pull on the tongue until the mouth is wide open (Fig. 13A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0013]). d.Look into the mouth and find the larynx (Fig. 13B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0013]). The trachea should light up as a bright spot. If not, poke lightly with the blunt insertion needle just below the larynx until the bright spot becomes visible. e.Insert the bent needle, about 1 cm, into the bright spot of the trachea. f.Slide the catheter into the trachea (Fig. 13C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0013]). You should feel some resistance before getting in. Put the catheter so that the attachment part is about 0.5 cm above the nose (Fig. 18B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0018]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/1094dd41-9107-4855-8313-21505c17ac06/cpz1488-fig-0013-m.jpg

Figure 13 Intubation showing proper handling of the mouse (A), insertion of the catheter in the trachea illuminated as a bright spot (B), and the mouse after the procedure with the optimal placement of the catheter (C). 7. Confirm if the intubation was done correctly. Attach the tubing of the intubation confirmation module to the catheter tube (Fig. 9E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0009]). Assess the correctness of intubation. If the LEDs start to blink left-right, on and off in synchronization with the breathing, intubation is done correctly. If not, restart procedure from step 5. Refer to Videos 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0001a] and 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002a] for the demonstration of how the module works.

The protocol below describes the measurement of mouse lung function without introduction of any modifying agent. This protocol requires the experimenter to have prior training with the assembly of the FlexiVentFX™ System and intubation of a mouse. Both prerequisite procedures are described above. For the management of the study, data acquisition, review, and recording, FlexiWare software is needed. Refer to the FlexiWare User Manual for setup, installation, and registration. Follow Support Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0002] for database management. Figure 14[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0014] shows an overview of the FlexiWare software interface.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/2a2e4b48-a628-40ac-a00a-88740710545a/cpz1488-fig-0014-m.jpg

Figure 14 Overview of the screen of the FlexiWare software. NOTE: All protocols involving animals must be reviewed and approved by the appropriate Animal Care and Use Committee and must follow regulations for the care and use of laboratory animals. Materials Assembled FlexiVentFX™ Base Unit and Module (Scireq Inc.; see Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0001]) FlexiWare Software (Scireq Inc.) Anesthetized and intubated mouse (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0004]) 12 × 12 × 4.2 cm styrofoam platform (see step 9b.i) Heating mat (Beurer, S8-S1) Pressure manometer 3.0 kPa (Scireq Inc.) 1. Assemble the FlexiVentFX™ System. Assemble the system as described in Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0001]. 2. Check the size of the database. For data integrity, the database cannot be larger than 1.5 GB. Check the size of the database file at D:\Flexivent_DB\. If the database is larger than 1.4 GB, create a new one according to Support Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0002], above. 3. Switch on the FlexiVentFX™ and start the software. The power switch of the FlexiVentFX™ is located on the left of the LCD on the main chassis (Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0002]). Start the software. Once the main menu of the software opens, click on Experimentation Session (Fig. 7[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0007]) to launch the experimentation module.

4. Select or create the study. In the study selection window, select the appropriate study. If the study you need is not defined yet (Fig. 15[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0015]): Click on the ‘Create a new Study’ button on the left bottom corner or go to File menu > New Study. Fill in the Title in the Study Definition Wizard Step 1 A naming convention applies, as detailed in the Support Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0002]. Fill in your complete name in the study Owner field. Fill in the objective, hypothesis, and protocol in steps 2 and 3. Assign the groups in step 4. At least one group needs to be defined. For example, we create only one group called ‘Default’. For other studies, define groups according to your needs. Assign subjects in step 5. Select the virtual mouse called ‘Setup’ or ‘Setupx’, where x is an integer, and move it to the right column. If there is no mouse with that name in the database, create it by clicking on ‘Subject Management’ in the bottom right corner of the window. Click on the mouse icon and the ‘+’ sign in the window that pops up. In the subject identifier, type Setup and in the ‘Last weight’ field put 25. Click OK. If the software complains that that mouse already exists in the database, rename it to Setupx. Check the study definition in step 6 and click on ‘Finish’. Select the study you just created and click ‘OK’.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/26756600-a121-4ab5-b0df-1e40e187c744/cpz1488-fig-0015-m.jpg

Figure 15 Steps of the Study Definition Wizard. 5. Select template and virtual ‘Setup’ mouse. Select the necessary study template (e.g., ‘CCP mouse mechanics scan’) and click ‘OK’. In the ‘Session properties’ window, fill in your full name in the ‘Operator’ field

Check that the piston arm is well mounted on the motor arm (see Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0001], step 2). Click ‘OK’. If only the ‘Setup’ or ‘Setupx’ mouse is defined in the study the ‘Subject weight’ window will pop-up. Click ‘OK’. If other mice have been defined, select the ‘Setup’ or ‘Setupx’ mouse from the list and move it to the right column by double-clicking on it or by selecting it. Click the arrow on the right, then click ‘OK’. 6. Calibrate channels if requested. a.Allow for the transducers to heat up, after which the ‘Calibration Wizard’ window will pop-up. b.If the calibration has expired, check the boxes in front of the channels and click ‘Next’. c.For step 2: First value: zero (atmosphere), attach the tubing of the manometer to the tubing of the FlexiVentFX™ system. Open the ‘3-way’ tap so that the tubing is connected to the open air (white tap, forming a cross with the three openings of the tap). Aspirate air with the syringe (Fig. 16A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0016]). d.For the ‘First value: zero (atmosphere)’ click ‘Next’. e.For step 3: Second Value: Known Pressure, close the ‘3-way’ tap (white tap over the side-branch opening) and inject air until the manometer shows 300 mm H2O of pressure, hold the syringe at that pressure (Fig. 16B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0016]), and click ‘Next’. Check that the value says 300 mm H2O, and click ‘Next’. Click ‘Next’ when the calibration results are shown. f.Repeat steps c–e for the airway opening pressure calibration. g.On the window ‘Calibration complete’, click ‘Finish’. h.On the window with the tube calibration, click ‘Cancel’. i.On the window with ‘Start default ventilation’, click ‘No’.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/676d1605-6cb4-4d59-8e38-d974546b58a1/cpz1488-fig-0016-m.jpg

Figure 16

Calibration of the channels using a pressure manometer. The connection of the manometer to the tubing of the FlexiVentFX™ system is shown with the 3-way tap in the opened (A) and (B) closed position. In the closed position, the air in the syringe was pumped in until the 300-mm water pressure mark.
7. Change subject and start tube calibration.
         
a.Take the mouse you need to measure out of its cage, write down its ID number on the report file, and weigh it.
b.Go to ‘Edit’ > ‘Edit Site Assignment’ in the FlexiWare software.
c.Double click on the mouse in the right column to remove it from the site. Uncheck the box ‘This experiment was terminal’ for mice that were intubated or for the virtual ‘Setup’ or ‘Setupx’ mouse.
d.Select the mouse to be measured from the list on the left and assign it to the measuring site by double-clicking on it or by clicking the arrow to the right.
e.Create a new mouse as described above if the mouse is not in the list.
Use the full mouse identifier as ‘Subject identifier’ and input the animal's weight. You can assign the mouse to an experimental group if needed. Mice will automatically be assigned to the first group defined if you do not assign groups.
f.Click ‘OK’ and confirm that the weight is correct in the ‘Subject weight’ window to start the tube calibration.
g.Close down a tube by putting a brown cap over it and attach it to the tubing of the FlexiVentFX™ (Fig. 17A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0017] and B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0017]). Click on ‘Next’ three times to start the ‘Closed tube calibration’.

h.Once the closed tube calibration has gone through all perturbations, remove the brown cap from the tube (Fig. 17C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0017]) and click ‘Next’ to start the ‘Open tube calibration’. Once this is done, the tube can be used for intubation. Tube calibration must pass an acceptable range for the intubation catheter to be useful for measurement. This can be checked in the Calibration Results. For the FX1 module Deep Inflation RI, the value should not exceed 2000 cmH2O·s/ml. For the FX2 module, the limit is 1125 cmH2O·s/ml.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/b8382de2-d83d-40c5-af23-45ebc6bcdce9/cpz1488-fig-0017-m.jpg

Figure 17 The steps of the Tube Calibration Wizard (A). The calibration of the intubation catheter tube in the closed (B) and opened (C) configuration. 8. Intubate the mouse. Follow Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-prot-0004], above. 9. Start the ventilation and attach the mouse to the ventilator. Start the ventilation by pressing the ‘Start default ventilation’ icon on the top menu or by selecting ‘Mouse default CMV’ in the menu on the right side of the screen (Fig. 14[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0014]). Attach the mouse to the ventilator and check the following points: Alignment of the tube and the trachea. Put the styrofoam platform in front of the FX module. The platform can be made from an ordinary Falcon tube holder or cover of a box. The tubing port will be above the platform (Fig. 17B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0017] and C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0017]). The intubation tube should form a straight line with the tubing port, and no angle should be present at all, or it will skew the measurement. We optimized the height of the styrofoam platform to be 4.2 cm. If necessary, raise the mouse a bit by putting some tissue under it. Insertion of the intubation tube in the trachea.

Check that the tube is not inserted too deeply (Fig. 18A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0018]), which can happen when attaching the mouse to the ventilator. The attachment of the tube should be approximately 0.5 cm from the nose of the mouse (Fig. 18B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0018]). Check that the tube attachment is fully inserted over its connector to reduce leakage to a minimum and to have a comparable situation as when the tube was calibrated.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/3009fd88-6932-4579-ba72-bcb6df4ce174/cpz1488-fig-0018-m.jpg

Figure 18 Intubated mouse attached to the ventilator of the FlexiVentFX™ system. Shown are the improper, deep insertion of the intubation tube (A) and the correct, optimal insertion (B). Check the respiratory curve (airway opening pressure). If the pressure is too high or irregular, the tube is probably in the esophagus. Remove the mouse immediately and redo the intubation. Please check Video 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0003a] for the appearance of the respiratory curves in different perturbations. This video cannot be streamed at this time, please download the video instead.[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/10652282-d292-4e31-9853-3781a33a2d82/cpz1488-vid-0003.mp4] Video The default protocol used by the Czech Centre for Phenogenomics for measuring lung function of unchallenged mice. The video shows the appearance of the deep inflation, SnapShot-150, Quick Prime-3, and Prime-8 perturbations 10. Check for leakage. Perform 2 deep inflation perturbations and check the top curve on the screen (Volume), it should increase fast at first and then reach a plateau. Please check Video 4[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0004a] for the appearance of the respiratory curves in deep perturbations. This video cannot be streamed at this time, please download the video instead.[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/cd2ff972-68e1-48bf-a6e2-314ff1d97ac3/cpz1488-vid-0004.mp4] Video Checking for leakage with deep inflation perturbation. The deep inflation protocol can serve as an additional information to check for any leakage in the system. A leakage-free set-up is indicated by the volume graph as a steady increase in volume followed by a plateau 11. Start the script.

Start the script by double-clicking it on the list on the right of the screen (Fig. 14[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0014]). The script will run for 1 min before doing two deep inflations. Check these to make sure there are no leaks (see step 10), and press ‘OK’ if no obvious leakage can be detected. Write down the number of failed perturbations on the report sheet during measurements. 12. Repeat invalid measurements (Fig. 19[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0019]). One minute after the end of the script, start to repeat the failed perturbations. Start the next perturbation at least 20 s after the previous one. As the timeline for the respiratory curve is 20 s, the perturbation can only be started when the previous one has completely disappeared from the curve.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/28e3e571-58f5-411f-8a86-0505913f35a9/cpz1488-fig-0019-m.jpg

Figure 19 The event log of the FlexiWare software showing invalid measurements. 13. Remove mouse from the FlexiVentFX™. Before removing from the FlexiVentFX™, make sure that the mouse is breathing by itself, as sometimes this is not the case due to the combination of anesthesia and forced ventilation. Switch back to default ventilation if the ventilator was set to hyperventilation. Leave this on for 1 min before proceeding to the next step. Switch off the ventilation by pressing the ‘Stop ventilation’ icon on top of the screen (Fig. 14[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0014]). The airway opening pressure curve should start to show rippling after a few seconds. If this does not appear after 15 s, switch the ventilation back on and wait for a few minutes, before retrying. Please refer to Video 5[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.488#cpz1488-fig-0005a] for a demonstration of this step. When the rippling appears, the mouse can be disconnected from the FlexiVentFX™ and extubated in case intubation was used. The ventilation can be stopped. When intubation was used and mice need to recover, put them on a heating mat.

This video cannot be streamed at this time, please download the video instead.[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/f9a53639-c1e2-4c5f-bba5-b58cd9c8ce5b/cpz1488-vid-0005.mp4]
Video
Checking the pressure Pao graph after performing the protocol can be used to check whether the mouse is breathing and has survived the procedure. The rippling negative pressure indicates that the mouse is breathing against the system.
14. Restart from step 7 for a new mouse.
In our institute, a macro was created to automatically extract the data to the Excel file exporter from the FlexiWare software. After extraction, the data summary is then calculated and added to new tabs in the same output file (one tab per perturbation type). The output file is then saved.
15. After the experimental session, clean and dry the adaptor, tubings, and system expiratory valve by following the manufacturer's instructions.
